an5.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an5.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an5.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an5.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five powers of a trainee.

an5.1:2.3.eng: The powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.

an5.1:2.4.eng: These are the five powers of a trainee.

an5.1:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an5.1:3.2.pli: ‘saddhābalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalena, hirībalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalena, ottappabalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalena, vīriyabalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalena, paññābalena samannāgatā bhavissāma sekhabalenā’ti.
an5.1:3.2.eng: ‘We will have the trainee’s powers of faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom.’

an5.1:3.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an5.1:3.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an5.1:3.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an5.10:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a disrespectful and irreverent mendicant with five qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an5.10:1.3.pli: Assaddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:1.3.eng: A disrespectful and irreverent mendicant who is faithless …

an5.10:1.4.pli: Ahiriko, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.

an5.10:1.5.pli: Anottappī, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.

an5.10:1.6.pli: Kusīto, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.

an5.10:1.7.pli: Duppañño, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:1.7.eng: witless can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an5.10:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu agāravo appatisso abhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:1.8.eng: A disrespectful and irreverent mendicant with these five qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

an5.10:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:2.1.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant with five qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

an5.10:2.3.pli: Saddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:2.3.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant who is faithful …

an5.10:2.4.pli: Hirīmā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu …pe… ottappī, bhikkhave, bhikkhu …pe… āraddhavīriyo, bhikkhave, bhikkhu …pe… paññavā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjituṃ.
an5.10:2.4.eng: conscientious … prudent … energetic … wise can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.

an5.10:2.5.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso bhabbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjitun”ti.
an5.10:2.5.eng: A respectful and reverent mendicant with these five qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.”

an5.100:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an5.100:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an5.100:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kakudho nāma koliyaputto āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa upaṭṭhāko adhunākālaṅkato aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno.
an5.100:1.3.eng: At that time the Koliyan named Kakudha—Venerable Mahāmoggallāna’s supporter—had recently passed away and been reborn in a certain host of mind-made gods.

an5.100:1.4.pli: Tassa evarūpo attabhāvapaṭilābho hoti—seyyathāpi nāma dve vā tīṇi vā māgadhakāni gāmakkhettāni.
an5.100:1.4.eng: His incarnation was two or three times the size of a Magadhan village with its fields.

an5.100:1.5.pli: So tena attabhāvapaṭilābhena neva attānaṃ no paraṃ byābādheti.
an5.100:1.5.eng: But with that incarnation he didn’t obstruct himself or others.

an5.100:2.1.pli: Atha kho kakudho devaputto yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kakudho devaputto āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:
an5.100:2.1.eng: Then the godling Kakudha went up to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

an5.100:2.2.eng: “Sir, this fixed desire arose in Devadatta:

an5.100:2.4.pli: Sahacittuppādā ca, bhante, devadatto tassā iddhiyā parihīno”ti.
an5.100:2.4.eng: And as that thought arose, Devadatta lost that psychic power.”

an5.100:2.5.eng: That’s what the godling Kakudha said.

an5.100:2.6.pli: Idaṃ vatvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
an5.100:2.6.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled Mahāmoggallāna, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

an5.100:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.100:3.1.eng: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

an5.100:4.1.pli: “Kakudho nāma, bhante, koliyaputto mamaṃ upaṭṭhāko adhunākālaṅkato aññataraṃ manomayaṃ kāyaṃ upapanno hoti.

an5.100:4.2.pli: Tassa evarūpo attabhāvapaṭilābho—seyyathāpi nāma dve vā tīṇi vā māgadhakāni gāmakkhettāni.

an5.100:4.3.pli: So tena attabhāvapaṭilābhena neva attānaṃ no paraṃ byābādheti.

an5.100:4.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, kakudho devaputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhante, kakudho devaputto maṃ etadavoca:

an5.100:4.7.pli: Sahacittuppādā ca, bhante, devadatto tassā iddhiyā parihīno’ti.

an5.100:4.9.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.

an5.100:5.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, moggallāna, kakudho devaputto cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
an5.100:5.1.eng: “But Moggallāna, did you encompass the godling Kakudha’s mind, and know that

an5.100:5.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci kakudho devaputto bhāsati sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti, no aññathā’”ti?
an5.100:5.2.eng: everything he says is correct and not otherwise?”

an5.100:5.3.pli: “Cetasā ceto paricca vidito me, bhante, kakudho devaputto:

an5.100:5.4.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñci kakudho devaputto bhāsati sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva hoti, no aññathā’”ti.

an5.100:5.7.pli: Idāni so moghapuriso attanāva attānaṃ pātukarissati.
an5.100:5.7.eng: Now that futile man Devadatta will expose himself by his own deeds.

an5.100:6.1.pli: Pañcime, moggallāna, satthāro santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an5.100:6.1.eng: Moggallāna, there are these five teachers found in the world.

an5.100:6.3.pli: Idha, moggallāna, ekacco satthā aparisuddhasīlo samāno ‘parisuddhasīlomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me sīlaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:6.3.eng: Firstly, some teacher with impure conduct claims: ‘I am pure in ethics. My ethical conduct is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:6.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ satthā aparisuddhasīlo samāno parisuddhasīlomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me sīlaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:6.5.eng: ‘This teacher has impure ethical conduct, but claims to be ethically pure.

an5.100:6.6.pli: Mayañceva kho pana gihīnaṃ āroceyyāma, nāssassa manāpaṃ.
an5.100:6.6.eng: They wouldn’t like it if we were to tell the laypeople.

an5.100:6.7.pli: Yaṃ kho panassa amanāpaṃ, kathaṃ naṃ mayaṃ tena samudācareyyāma:
an5.100:6.7.eng: And how could we treat them in a way that they don’t like?

an5.100:6.8.eng: But they consent to robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.100:6.9.pli: yaṃ tumo karissati tumova tena paññāyissatī’ti.
an5.100:6.9.eng: They themselves will be recognized by their own deeds.’

an5.100:6.10.pli: Evarūpaṃ kho, moggallāna, satthāraṃ sāvakā sīlato rakkhanti;
an5.100:6.10.eng: The disciples of such a teacher cover up their teacher’s conduct,

an5.100:6.11.pli: evarūpo ca pana satthā sāvakehi sīlato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsati.
an5.100:6.11.eng: and the teacher expects them to do so.

an5.100:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, moggallāna, idhekacco satthā aparisuddhājīvo samāno ‘parisuddhājīvomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddho me ājīvo pariyodāto asaṅkiliṭṭho’ti.
an5.100:7.1.eng: Furthermore, some teacher with impure livelihood claims: ‘I am pure in livelihood. My livelihood is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:7.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ satthā aparisuddhājīvo samāno parisuddhājīvomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddho me ājīvo pariyodāto asaṅkiliṭṭho’ti.
an5.100:7.3.eng: ‘This teacher has impure livelihood, but claims to have pure livelihood.

an5.100:7.4.pli: Mayañceva kho pana gihīnaṃ āroceyyāma, nāssassa manāpaṃ.
an5.100:7.4.eng: They wouldn’t like it if we were to tell the laypeople.

an5.100:7.5.pli: Yaṃ kho panassa amanāpaṃ, kathaṃ naṃ mayaṃ tena samudācareyyāma:
an5.100:7.5.eng: And how could we treat them in a way that they don’t like?

an5.100:7.6.eng: But they consent to robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.100:7.7.pli: yaṃ tumo karissati tumova tena paññāyissatī’ti.
an5.100:7.7.eng: They themselves will be recognized by their own deeds.’

an5.100:7.8.pli: Evarūpaṃ kho, moggallāna, satthāraṃ sāvakā ājīvato rakkhanti;
an5.100:7.8.eng: The disciples of such a teacher cover up their teacher’s livelihood,

an5.100:7.9.pli: evarūpo ca pana satthā sāvakehi ājīvato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsati.
an5.100:7.9.eng: and the teacher expects them to do so.

an5.100:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, moggallāna, idhekacco satthā aparisuddhadhammadesano samāno ‘parisuddhadhammadesanomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhā me dhammadesanā pariyodātā asaṅkiliṭṭhā’ti.
an5.100:8.1.eng: Furthermore, some teacher with impure teaching claims: ‘I am pure in teaching. My teaching is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:8.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ satthā aparisuddhadhammadesano samāno parisuddhadhammadesanomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhā me dhammadesanā pariyodātā asaṅkiliṭṭhā’ti.
an5.100:8.3.eng: ‘This teacher has impure teaching, but claims to have pure teaching.

an5.100:8.4.pli: Mayañceva kho pana gihīnaṃ āroceyyāma, nāssassa manāpaṃ.
an5.100:8.4.eng: They wouldn’t like it if we were to tell the laypeople.

an5.100:8.5.pli: Yaṃ kho panassa amanāpaṃ, kathaṃ naṃ mayaṃ tena samudācareyyāma:
an5.100:8.5.eng: And how could we treat them in a way that they don’t like?

an5.100:8.6.eng: But they consent to robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.100:8.7.pli: yaṃ tumo karissati tumova tena paññāyissatī’ti.
an5.100:8.7.eng: They themselves will be recognized by their own deeds.’

an5.100:8.8.pli: Evarūpaṃ kho, moggallāna, satthāraṃ sāvakā dhammadesanato rakkhanti;
an5.100:8.8.eng: The disciples of such a teacher cover up their teacher’s teaching,

an5.100:8.9.pli: evarūpo ca pana satthā sāvakehi dhammadesanato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsati.
an5.100:8.9.eng: and the teacher expects them to do so.

an5.100:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, moggallāna, idhekacco satthā aparisuddhaveyyākaraṇo samāno ‘parisuddhaveyyākaraṇomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me veyyākaraṇaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:9.1.eng: Furthermore, some teacher with impure answers claims: ‘I am pure in how I answer. My answers are pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:9.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ satthā aparisuddhaveyyākaraṇo samāno parisuddhaveyyākaraṇomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me veyyākaraṇaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:9.3.eng: ‘This teacher has impure answers, but claims to have pure answers.

an5.100:9.4.pli: Mayañceva kho pana gihīnaṃ āroceyyāma, nāssassa manāpaṃ.
an5.100:9.4.eng: They wouldn’t like it if we were to tell the laypeople.

an5.100:9.5.pli: Yaṃ kho panassa amanāpaṃ, kathaṃ naṃ mayaṃ tena samudācareyyāma:
an5.100:9.5.eng: And how could we treat them in a way that they don’t like?

an5.100:9.6.eng: But they consent to robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.100:9.7.pli: yaṃ tumo karissati tumova tena paññāyissatī’ti.
an5.100:9.7.eng: They themselves will be recognized by their own deeds.’

an5.100:9.8.pli: Evarūpaṃ kho, moggallāna, satthāraṃ sāvakā veyyākaraṇato rakkhanti;
an5.100:9.8.eng: The disciples of such a teacher cover up their teacher’s answers,

an5.100:9.9.pli: evarūpo ca pana satthā sāvakehi veyyākaraṇato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsati.
an5.100:9.9.eng: and the teacher expects them to do so.

an5.100:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, moggallāna, idhekacco satthā aparisuddhañāṇadassano samāno ‘parisuddhañāṇadassanomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me ñāṇadassanaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:10.1.eng: Furthermore, some teacher with impure knowledge and vision claims: ‘I am pure in knowledge and vision. My knowledge and vision are pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:10.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho bhavaṃ satthā aparisuddhañāṇadassano samāno parisuddhañāṇadassanomhī’ti paṭijānāti ‘parisuddhaṃ me ñāṇadassanaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:10.3.eng: ‘This teacher has impure knowledge and vision, but claims to have pure knowledge and vision.

an5.100:10.4.pli: Mayañceva kho pana gihīnaṃ āroceyyāma, nāssassa manāpaṃ.
an5.100:10.4.eng: They wouldn’t like it if we were to tell the laypeople.

an5.100:10.5.pli: Yaṃ kho panassa amanāpaṃ, kathaṃ naṃ mayaṃ tena samudācareyyāma:
an5.100:10.5.eng: And how could we treat them in a way that they don’t like?

an5.100:10.6.eng: But they consent to robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.100:10.7.pli: yaṃ tumo karissati tumova tena paññāyissatī’ti.
an5.100:10.7.eng: They themselves will be recognized by their own deeds.’

an5.100:10.8.pli: Evarūpaṃ kho, moggallāna, satthāraṃ sāvakā ñāṇadassanato rakkhanti;
an5.100:10.8.eng: The disciples of such a teacher cover up their teacher’s knowledge and vision,

an5.100:10.9.pli: evarūpo ca pana satthā sāvakehi ñāṇadassanato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsati.
an5.100:10.9.eng: and the teacher expects them to do so.

an5.100:10.10.pli: Ime kho, moggallāna, pañca satthāro santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an5.100:10.10.eng: These are the five teachers found in the world.

an5.100:11.1.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, moggallāna, parisuddhasīlo samāno ‘parisuddhasīlomhī’ti paṭijānāmi ‘parisuddhaṃ me sīlaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:11.1.eng: But Moggallāna, I have pure ethical conduct, and I claim: ‘I am pure in ethical conduct. My ethical conduct is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:11.2.pli: Na ca maṃ sāvakā sīlato rakkhanti, na cāhaṃ sāvakehi sīlato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsāmi.
an5.100:11.2.eng: My disciples don’t cover up my conduct, and I don’t expect them to.

an5.100:11.3.pli: Parisuddhājīvo samāno ‘parisuddhājīvomhī’ti paṭijānāmi ‘parisuddho me ājīvo pariyodāto asaṅkiliṭṭho’ti.
an5.100:11.3.eng: I have pure livelihood, and I claim: ‘I am pure in livelihood. My livelihood is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:11.4.pli: Na ca maṃ sāvakā ājīvato rakkhanti, na cāhaṃ sāvakehi ājīvato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsāmi.
an5.100:11.4.eng: My disciples don’t cover up my livelihood, and I don’t expect them to.

an5.100:11.5.pli: Parisuddhadhammadesano samāno ‘parisuddhadhammadesanomhī’ti paṭijānāmi ‘parisuddhā me dhammadesanā pariyodātā asaṅkiliṭṭhā’ti.
an5.100:11.5.eng: I have pure teaching, and I claim: ‘I am pure in teaching. My teaching is pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:11.6.pli: Na ca maṃ sāvakā dhammadesanato rakkhanti, na cāhaṃ sāvakehi dhammadesanato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsāmi.
an5.100:11.6.eng: My disciples don’t cover up my teaching, and I don’t expect them to.

an5.100:11.7.pli: Parisuddhaveyyākaraṇo samāno ‘parisuddhaveyyākaraṇomhī’ti paṭijānāmi ‘parisuddhaṃ me veyyākaraṇaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:11.7.eng: I have pure answers, and I claim: ‘I am pure in how I answer. My answers are pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:11.8.pli: Na ca maṃ sāvakā veyyākaraṇato rakkhanti, na cāhaṃ sāvakehi veyyākaraṇato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsāmi.
an5.100:11.8.eng: My disciples don’t cover up my answers, and I don’t expect them to.

an5.100:11.9.pli: Parisuddhañāṇadassano samāno ‘parisuddhañāṇadassanomhī’ti paṭijānāmi ‘parisuddhaṃ me ñāṇadassanaṃ pariyodātaṃ asaṅkiliṭṭhan’ti.
an5.100:11.9.eng: I have pure knowledge and vision, and I claim: ‘I am pure in knowledge and vision. My knowledge and vision are pure, bright, uncorrupted.’

an5.100:11.10.pli: Na ca maṃ sāvakā ñāṇadassanato rakkhanti, na cāhaṃ sāvakehi ñāṇadassanato rakkhaṃ paccāsīsāmī”ti.
an5.100:11.10.eng: My disciples don’t cover up my knowledge and vision, and I don’t expect them to.”

an5.101:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five qualities make a trainee assured.

an5.101:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, paññavā hoti.
an5.101:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, ethical, learned, energetic, and wise.

an5.101:2.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, assaddhassa sārajjaṃ hoti, saddhassa taṃ sārajjaṃ na hoti.
an5.101:2.1.eng: A person of faith doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who lacks faith.

an5.101:2.2.eng: So this quality makes a trainee assured.

an5.101:3.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sārajjaṃ hoti, sīlavato taṃ sārajjaṃ na hoti.
an5.101:3.1.eng: An ethical person doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who is unethical.

an5.101:3.2.eng: So this quality makes a trainee assured.

an5.101:4.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, appassutassa sārajjaṃ hoti, bahussutassa taṃ sārajjaṃ na hoti.
an5.101:4.1.eng: A learned person doesn’t have the insecurities of a person of little learning.

an5.101:4.2.eng: So this quality makes a trainee assured.

an5.101:5.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, kusītassa sārajjaṃ hoti, āraddhavīriyassa taṃ sārajjaṃ na hoti.
an5.101:5.1.eng: An energetic person doesn’t have the insecurities of a lazy person.

an5.101:5.2.eng: So this quality makes a trainee assured.

an5.101:6.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, duppaññassa sārajjaṃ hoti, paññavato taṃ sārajjaṃ na hoti.
an5.101:6.1.eng: A wise person doesn’t have the insecurities of someone who is witless.

an5.101:6.2.eng: So this quality makes a trainee assured.

an5.101:6.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca sekhavesārajjakaraṇā dhammā”ti.
an5.101:6.3.eng: These are the five qualities that make a trainee assured.”

an5.102:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ussaṅkitaparisaṅkito hoti pāpabhikkhūti api akuppadhammopi.
an5.102:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, even if a monk is of impeccable character, he might be suspected and distrusted as a ‘bad monk’ for five reasons.

an5.102:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vesiyāgocaro vā hoti, vidhavāgocaro vā hoti, thullakumārikāgocaro vā hoti, paṇḍakagocaro vā hoti, bhikkhunīgocaro vā hoti.
an5.102:2.2.eng: It’s when a monk resorts to prostitutes, widows, voluptuous girls, eunuchs, or nuns for alms.

an5.102:3.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu ussaṅkitaparisaṅkito hoti pāpabhikkhūti api akuppadhammopī”ti.
an5.102:3.1.eng: Even if a monk is of impeccable character, he might be suspected and distrusted as a ‘bad monk’ for these five reasons.”

an5.103:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati, nillopampi harati, ekāgārikampi karoti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.
an5.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a master thief with five factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.

an5.103:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito ca hoti, gahananissito ca, balavanissito ca, bhogacāgī ca, ekacārī ca.
an5.103:1.3.eng: A master thief relies on rough ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful; they pay bribes, and they act alone.

an5.103:2.1.eng: And how does a master thief rely on rough ground?

an5.103:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro nadīviduggaṃ vā nissito hoti pabbatavisamaṃ vā.
an5.103:2.2.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on inaccessible riverlands or rugged mountains.

an5.103:2.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito hoti.
an5.103:2.3.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on rough ground.

an5.103:3.1.eng: And how does a master thief rely on thick cover?

an5.103:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro tiṇagahanaṃ vā nissito hoti rukkhagahanaṃ vā rodhaṃ vā mahāvanasaṇḍaṃ vā.
an5.103:3.2.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on thick grass, thick trees, a blind spot, or a large forest grove.

an5.103:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro gahananissito hoti.
an5.103:3.3.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on thick cover.

an5.103:4.1.eng: And how does a master thief rely on the powerful?

an5.103:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattānaṃ vā nissito hoti.
an5.103:4.2.eng: It’s when a master thief relies on rulers or their chief ministers.

an5.103:4.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇissantī’ti.
an5.103:4.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’

an5.103:4.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tyassa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇanti.

an5.103:4.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro balavanissito hoti.
an5.103:4.6.eng: That’s how a master thief relies on the powerful.

an5.103:5.1.eng: And how does a master thief pay bribes?

an5.103:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro aḍḍho hoti mahaddhano mahābhogo.
an5.103:5.2.eng: It’s when a master thief is rich, affluent, and wealthy.

an5.103:5.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ito bhogena paṭisantharissāmī’ti.
an5.103:5.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, I’ll settle it with a bribe.’

an5.103:5.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tato bhogena paṭisantharati.

an5.103:5.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro bhogacāgī hoti.
an5.103:5.6.eng: That’s how a master thief pays bribes.

an5.103:6.1.eng: And how does a master thief act alone?

an5.103:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro ekakova gahaṇāni kattā hoti.
an5.103:6.2.eng: It’s when a master thief carries out robbery all alone.

an5.103:6.4.eng: So that their secret plans are not leaked to others.

an5.103:6.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro ekacārī hoti.
an5.103:6.5.eng: That’s how a master thief acts alone.

an5.103:7.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati nillopampi harati ekāgārikampi karoti paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.
an5.103:7.1.eng: A master thief with these five factors breaks into houses, plunders wealth, steals from isolated buildings, and commits highway robbery.

an5.103:8.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato pāpabhikkhu khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an5.103:8.1.eng: In the same way, when a bad mendicant has five qualities, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an5.103:8.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito ca hoti, gahananissito ca, balavanissito ca, bhogacāgī ca, ekacārī ca.
an5.103:8.3.eng: A bad mendicant relies on rough ground, on thick cover, and on the powerful; they pay bribes, and they act alone.

an5.103:9.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on rough ground?

an5.103:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, visamena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, visamena manokammena samannāgato hoti.
an5.103:9.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant has unethical conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an5.103:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito hoti.
an5.103:9.3.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on rough ground.

an5.103:10.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on thick cover?

an5.103:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu micchādiṭṭhiko hoti antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgato.
an5.103:10.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.

an5.103:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu gahananissito hoti.
an5.103:10.3.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on thick cover.

an5.103:11.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant rely on the powerful?

an5.103:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattānaṃ vā nissito hoti.
an5.103:11.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant relies on rulers or their chief ministers.

an5.103:11.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇissantī’ti.
an5.103:11.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, these rulers or their chief ministers will speak in my defense in the case.’

an5.103:11.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tyassa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṃ bhaṇanti.

an5.103:11.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu balavanissito hoti.
an5.103:11.6.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant relies on the powerful.

an5.103:12.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant pay bribes?

an5.103:12.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

an5.103:12.4.pli: ‘sace maṃ koci kiñci vakkhati, ito lābhena paṭisantharissāmī’ti.
an5.103:12.4.eng: ‘If anyone accuses me of anything, I’ll settle it with a bribe.’

an5.103:12.5.pli: Sace naṃ koci kiñci āha, tato lābhena paṭisantharati.

an5.103:12.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu bhogacāgī hoti.
an5.103:12.6.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant pays bribes.

an5.103:13.1.eng: And how does a bad mendicant act alone?

an5.103:13.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu ekakova paccantimesu janapadesu nivāsaṃ kappeti.
an5.103:13.2.eng: It’s when a bad mendicant dwells alone in the borderlands.

an5.103:13.3.pli: So tattha kulāni upasaṅkamanto lābhaṃ labhati.
an5.103:13.3.eng: They visit families there to acquire material things.

an5.103:13.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu ekacārī hoti.
an5.103:13.4.eng: That’s how a bad mendicant acts alone.

an5.103:14.1.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato pāpabhikkhu khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavatī”ti.
an5.103:14.1.eng: When a bad mendicant possesses these five qualities, they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they create much wickedness.”

an5.104:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo hoti.
an5.104:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is a delicate ascetic of ascetics.

an5.104:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yācitova bahulaṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuñjati, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjati, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ senāsanaṃ paribhuñjati, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ paribhuñjati, appaṃ ayācito.
an5.104:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant usually uses only what they’ve been invited to accept—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—rarely using them without invitation.

an5.104:2.3.pli: Yehi kho pana sabrahmacārīhi saddhiṃ viharati, tyassa manāpeneva bahulaṃ kāyakammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena; manāpeneva bahulaṃ vacīkammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena; manāpeneva bahulaṃ manokammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena;
an5.104:2.3.eng: When living with other spiritual practitioners, they usually find themselves treated agreeably by them by way of body, speech, and mind, and rarely disagreeably.

an5.104:2.4.eng: And they are usually presented with agreeable things by them, rarely with disagreeable ones.

an5.104:2.5.pli: Yāni kho pana tāni vedayitāni pittasamuṭṭhānāni vā semhasamuṭṭhānāni vā vātasamuṭṭhānāni vā sannipātikāni vā utupariṇāmajāni vā visamaparihārajāni vā opakkamikāni vā kammavipākajāni vā, tānissa na bahudeva uppajjanti.
an5.104:2.5.eng: They’re healthy, so the various unpleasant feelings—stemming from disorders of bile, phlegm, wind, or their conjunction; or caused by change in weather, by not taking care of themselves, by overexertion, or as the result of past deeds—usually don’t come up.

an5.104:2.6.pli: Appābādho hoti, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an5.104:2.6.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.104:2.7.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an5.104:2.7.eng: And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.104:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo hoti.
an5.104:2.8.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is a delicate ascetic of ascetics.

an5.104:3.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya: ‘samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo’ti, mameva taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya: ‘samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo’ti.
an5.104:3.1.eng: And if anyone should be rightly called a delicate ascetic of ascetics, it’s me.

an5.104:3.2.pli: Ahañhi, bhikkhave, yācitova bahulaṃ cīvaraṃ paribhuñjāmi, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjāmi, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ senāsanaṃ paribhuñjāmi, appaṃ ayācito; yācitova bahulaṃ gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ paribhuñjāmi, appaṃ ayācito.
an5.104:3.2.eng: For I usually use only what I’ve been invited to accept.

an5.104:3.3.pli: Yehi kho pana bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ viharāmi, te maṃ manāpeneva bahulaṃ kāyakammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena; manāpeneva bahulaṃ vacīkammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena; manāpeneva bahulaṃ manokammena samudācaranti, appaṃ amanāpena;
an5.104:3.3.eng: When living with other mendicants, I am usually treated agreeably by them.

an5.104:3.4.eng: And I usually present them with agreeable things.

an5.104:3.5.pli: Yāni kho pana tāni vedayitāni—pittasamuṭṭhānāni vā semhasamuṭṭhānāni vā vātasamuṭṭhānāni vā sannipātikāni vā utupariṇāmajāni vā visamaparihārajāni vā opakkamikāni vā kammavipākajāni vā—tāni me na bahudeva uppajjanti. Appābādhohamasmi.

an5.104:3.6.pli: catunnaṃ kho panasmi jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an5.104:3.6.eng: I get the four absorptions when I want, without trouble or difficulty.

an5.104:3.7.eng: And I’ve realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life.

an5.104:4.1.pli: Yañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya: ‘samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo’ti, mameva taṃ, bhikkhave, sammā vadamāno vadeyya: ‘samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo’”ti.
an5.104:4.1.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a delicate ascetic of ascetics, it’s me.”

an5.105:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five ways of living comfortably.

an5.105:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ … mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
an5.105:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.

an5.105:1.4.pli: Yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpehi sīlehi sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
an5.105:1.4.eng: They live according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an5.105:1.5.pli: Yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
an5.105:1.5.eng: They live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

an5.105:1.6.eng: These are the five ways of living comfortably.”
